questions.question_text:
A security analyst is troubleshooting a scenario in which an operator should only be allowed to reboot remote hosts but not perform other activities. The analyst inspects the following portions of different configuration files:
Configuration file 1:

Operator ALL=/sbin/reboot -
Configuration file 2:
Command=`/sbin/shutdown now`, no-x11-forwarding, no-pty, ssh-dss
Configuration file 3:
Operator:x:1000:1000::/home/operator:/bin/bash
Which of the following explains why an intended operator cannot perform the intended action?

discussion.content:
Answer is B.

Configuration file 2 should read:
Command=”/usr/bin/sudo /sbin/reboot”,no-x11-forwarding,no-pty ssh-dss ****

you would then do:
ssh Operator@host ‘echo PASSWORD | /usr/bin/sudo -S /sbin/reboot’

You don’t need a pty session to run the remote command, although sudoers should really say Operator ALL=NOPASSWD: /sbin/reboot to allow this remotely without password prompt. .

D
The shell command restrictions ARE misconfigured.... in that they do not allow pty-sessions. Both answers are correct, but I believe D is more specifically correct. If you can't open a PTY session, you won't be able to send the command. No PTY basically means you can only log in through a serial cable, it will disable ssh connections. No session means you can't send commands like reboot (even though reboot is specifically enabled in config file 1).
verified this question with some developers and answer is B.

choices.A: The sudoers file is locked down to an incorrect command
choices.B: SSH command shell restrictions are misconfigured
choices.D: The SSH command is not allowing a pty session

questions.question_text:
The director of sales asked the development team for some small changes to increase the usability of an application used by the sales team. Prior security reviews of the code showed no significant vulnerabilities, and since the changes were small, they were given a peer review and then pushed to the live environment. Subsequent vulnerability scans now show numerous flaws that were not present in the previous versions of the code.
Which of the following is an SDLC best practice that should have been followed?

discussion.content: B. Regression test is used after a change to validate that inputs and outputs are correct.

questions.question_text: An organization is engaged in international business operations and is required to comply with various legal frameworks. In addition to changes in legal frameworks, which of the following is a primary purpose of a compliance management program?

choices.A: Following new requirements that result from contractual obligations
choices.C: Responding to changes in regulatory requirements
choices.B: Answering requests from auditors that relate to e-discovery
choices.D: Developing organizational policies that relate to hiring and termination procedures

discussion.content: C. Responding to changes in regulatory requirements
General rule of thumb for anything involving legal in the question, the answer is usually about referring to legal or referring to a framework or a law.

According to wikipedia: "Compliance refers to adhering with the mandated boundaries (laws and regulations) and voluntary boundaries (company's policies, procedures, etc.)."
However, the answer to the question seems to suggest that compliance on applies to government laws and regulations, not an organization's internal policies. 
So which is it?

comments.content: The reason A is NOT correct is that the “-t SOA” makes the command specifically look for name servers with a “Start of Authority” record (the syntax also isn't really right, but that's pretty normal for *nix commands on a CompTIA exam...). Since we’re looking for SMTP we know it needs to be mail so we want an MX record.

discussion.content: I would also use "dig" to find this out.

Selected Answer: B
B. dig company.org mx

questions.question_text:
Company.org has requested a black-box security assessment be performed on key cyber terrain. One area of concern is the company's SMTP services. The security assessor wants to run reconnaissance before taking any additional action and wishes to determine which SMTP server is Internet-facing.
Which of the following commands should the assessor use to determine this information?

discussion.content: "must be retested for interoperability with the new software" It does not say that they need to be tested for effectiveness of the antivirus solution. User acceptance testing feels right to me.

comments.content: You might be right. But how are users supposed to know if the antivirus software is working?

discussion.content: My guess with this question is that the users know how to operate the software and instruments, so can report back if the new solution doesn't work as well as the old one.

According to the FDA Design Control Guidance for Medical Device Manufacturers in section 802.30(h) Design transfer (specifically about implementing new software/devices in new medical facilities) under subsection II. Discussions and Points to Consider- It specifically says "Manufacturers should use processes best suited to their needs.
However, whatever the processes may be, it is important that the design controls are
applied in an appropriate manner" and further goes on to say that system design documentation must be followed to ensure that the device is working as designed. With that, I feel that A is the more correct answer. Granted, that document is from 1997- so things may have changed a bit, but I honestly don't see how "user acceptance training" could possibly ensure the software is working properly.. I'm sure there's a more updated document, but I'm a bit busy studying for a particular test at the moment. Some of you may have heard of it! Lol

comments.content:
Of course you follow the system design documentation as best you can, but you don't really know if everything is working correctly until you test it. The question is asking: what is the best way to test it. 
Today, when you buy a bicycle, you usually have to assemble it. Of course you follow the instructions, but you don't really know if you have it put together correctly until you test it out.

discussion.content:
Not entirely comfortable with this answer. 
They need to "ensure the software and instruments are working as designed." 
How will the users know if antivirus software is working as designed, unless or until, they get a virus?

comments.content:
IMO: not really. Most users do not know how to thoroughly test software. For example, software prompts for data, the user gives it data, and the software seems to work, as far as the user knows. But a skilled hacker might know how to inject malware into the system. How are users supposed to know if the antivirus software is working as expected? 
A peer review might make more sense. The software and system is tested by somebody who knows something about software and system testing.

Agreed. But seems like another one of those pooly worded questions. If the testing is done that all softwares are working the same as they were before the new software then uat makes sense as the answer.

"How will the users know if antivirus software is working as designed, unless or until, they get a virus?" 
> just create one and test the AV?

questions.question_text:
A medical device company is implementing a new COTS antivirus solution in its manufacturing plant. All validated machines and instruments must be retested for interoperability with the new software.
Which of the following would BEST ensure the software and instruments are working as designed?
